cluster.display: In the case of C → Q, our __________ variable X is categorical.
In the case of C → Q, our explanatory variable __________ is categorical.
In the case of C → Q, our explanatory variable X is __________.
In the case of C → Q, our __________ variable Y is quantitative.
In the case of C → Q, our response variable __________ is quantitative.
In the case of C → Q, our response variable Y is __________.
Samples are __________ when each observation in one sample is matched with an observation in the other sample.
Samples are dependent when each observation in one sample is __________ with an observation in the other sample.
Samples are dependent when each __________ in one sample is matched with an __________ in the other sample.
When comparing __________ independent sample means, we use a __________-sample t-test.
When comparing two __________ sample means, we use a two-sample t-test.
When comparing two independent sample means, we use a __________ t-test.
When comparing two independent sample means, we use a two-sample __________.
A __________ t-test looks at the effect of a two-valued categorical explanatory variable on a quantitative response variable.
A two-sample t-test looks at the effect of a two-valued __________ explanatory variable on a quantitative response variable.
A two-sample t-test looks at the effect of a two-valued categorical explanatory variable on a __________ response variable.
The __________ hypothesis of a two-sample t-test states that the difference between μ<sub>1</sub> and μ<sub>2</sub> is 0, or that μ<sub>1</sub> = μ<sub>2</sub>.
The null hypothesis of a __________ t-test states that the difference between μ<sub>1</sub> and μ<sub>2</sub> is 0, or that μ<sub>1</sub> = μ<sub>2</sub>.
The null hypothesis of a two-sample t-test states that the __________ between μ<sub>1</sub> and μ<sub>2</sub> is 0, or that μ<sub>1</sub> = μ<sub>2</sub>.
The null hypothesis of a two-sample t-test states that the difference between μ<sub>1</sub> and μ<sub>2</sub> is __________, or that μ<sub>1</sub> = μ<sub>2</sub>.
The __________ of a two-sample t-test is zero.
The null value of a two-sample t-test is __________.
The __________ for a two-sample t-test measures the difference between what the data tells us about the parameter μ<sub>1</sub> - μ<sub>2</sub> and the null value measured in standard errors.
The test statistic for a two-sample t-test measures the __________ between what the data tells us about the parameter μ<sub>1</sub> - μ<sub>2</sub> and the null value measured in standard errors.
The test statistic for a two-sample t-test measures the difference between what the data tells us about the parameter μ<sub>1</sub> - μ<sub>2</sub> and the null value measured in __________.
By using a __________ confidence interval we can quantify the effect of the explanatory categorical variable on the quantitative response variable.
By using a 0.95 confidence interval we can __________ the effect of the explanatory categorical variable on the quantitative response variable.
By using a 0.95 confidence interval we can quantify the __________ of the explanatory categorical variable on the quantitative response variable.
If the __________ of 0 is outside of the 95% confidence interval, we have significant evidence to reject H<sub>0</sub>.
If the null value of __________ is outside of the 95% confidence interval, we have significant evidence to reject H<sub>0</sub>.
If the null value of 0 is outside of the 95% confidence interval, we have __________ evidence to reject H<sub>0</sub>.
If the null value of 0 is outside of the 95% confidence interval, we have significant evidence to __________ H<sub>0</sub>.
If the __________ of 0 is inside of the 95% confidence interval, we do not have enough evidence to reject H<sub>0</sub>.
If the null value of 0 is __________ of the 95% confidence interval, we do not have enough evidence to reject H<sub>0</sub>.
If the null value of 0 is inside of the 95% confidence interval, we do not have enough evidence to __________ H<sub>0</sub>.
When comparing __________ pairs from dependent samples, we conduct a paired t-test.
When comparing matched pairs from __________ samples, we conduct a paired t-test.
When comparing matched pairs from dependent samples, we conduct a __________ t-test.
When comparing matched pairs from dependent samples, we conduct a paired __________.
If two samples are __________ by subject, both samples have the same subject pool and have measured their subjects twice.
If two samples are paired by __________, both samples have the same __________ pool and have measured their __________s twice.
If two samples are paired by subject, both samples have the same subject pool and have measured their subjects __________.
When comparing two means from __________ samples, we are making an inference about a single mean: the mean of differences.
When comparing two means from dependent samples, we are making an inference about a __________ mean: the mean of differences.
When comparing two means from dependent samples, we are making an inference about a single mean: the mean of __________.
When comparing two means from dependent samples, we are making an __________ about a single mean: the mean of differences.
When comparing two means from __________ samples, we reduce the two samples to one by calculating the difference between the observations of each pair.
When comparing two means from dependent samples, we reduce the two samples to __________ by calculating the difference between the observations of each pair.
When comparing two means from dependent samples, we reduce the two samples to one by calculating the __________ between the observations of each pair.
When comparing two means from dependent samples, we reduce the two samples to one by calculating the difference between the __________ of each pair.
The __________ hypothesis for a paired t-test will be H<sub>0</sub>: μ<sub>d</sub> = 0, stating that the difference between the means equals zero.
The null hypothesis for a __________ t-test will be H<sub>0</sub>: μ<sub>d</sub> = 0, stating that the difference between the means equals zero.
The null hypothesis for a paired t-test will be H<sub>0</sub>: μ<sub>d</sub> = 0, stating that the __________ between the means equals zero.
The null hypothesis for a paired t-test will be H<sub>0</sub>: μ<sub>d</sub> = 0, stating that the difference between the means equals __________.
__________, or analysis of variance, is used when we have more than two independent samples.
ANOVA, or analysis of __________, is used when we have more than two independent samples.
ANOVA, or analysis of variance, is used when we have __________ than two independent samples.
ANOVA, or analysis of variance, is used when we have more than two __________ samples.
ANOVA, or analysis of variance, is used when we have more than __________ independent samples.
The __________ hypothesis of an ANOVA F-test states that all means are equal.
The null hypothesis of an __________ F-test states that all means are equal.
The null hypothesis of an ANOVA F-test states that all __________ are equal.
The null hypothesis of an ANOVA F-test states that all means are __________.
The __________ hypothesis of an ANOVA F-test states that not all means are equal, but does not specify where the difference may be.
The alternative hypothesis of an __________ F-test states that not all means are equal, but does not specify where the difference may be.
The alternative hypothesis of an ANOVA F-test states that not all means are __________, but does not specify where the difference may be.
The alternative hypothesis of an ANOVA F-test states that not all means are equal, but does not specify where the __________ may be.
__________ measures variation between the sample means.
ANOVA measures __________ between the sample means.
ANOVA measures variation between the sample __________.
The __________ test statistic of an ANOVA compares the variation among sample means to the variation within each sample.
The F test statistic of an ANOVA compares the __________ among sample means to the __________ within each sample.
The F __________ of an ANOVA compares the variation among sample means to the variation within each sample.
The __________ F we have, the more evidence we have against H<sub>0</sub>.
The larger __________ we have, the more evidence we have against H<sub>0</sub>.
The larger F we have, the __________ evidence we have against H<sub>0</sub>.
The larger F we have, the more evidence we have __________ H<sub>0</sub>.
A large __________ value will occur when there is more variation among the sample means than there is within the samples themselves.
A large F value will occur when there is __________ variation among the sample means than there is within the samples themselves.
A large F value will occur when there is more __________ among the sample means than there is within the samples themselves.
We can only use an __________ when the populations have relatively equal σ.
We can only use an F-test when the __________ have relatively equal σ.
We can only use an F-test when the populations have relatively __________ σ.
